isis.stitle: TEST EQUIPMENT AND CONNECTOR REPAIR - CONNECTOR REPAIR - PACKARD CONNECTORS

svcsubproc.title: Weather Pack Series Connector Repair
svcsubproc.para: Weather Pack connector terminals use the flex-pin and lap-lock terminal design. Weather Pack terminals have dual lock tangs which lock the terminal into the connector cavity and prevent backing out. In addition, Weather Pack terminals have serrated core crimp wings. The terminals also have cable seal crimp wings to reduce strain on the cable core and assure proper position of the cable seal on the cable. Refer to Additional Connectors, which shows various additional Packard connectors.

step1.para: Disconnect the connector bodies ( Figure 42). Unlatch and open the secondary lock on the connector.
Remove terminals using Weather Pack terminal removal tool (12014012) or equivalent ( Figure 43).
Cut wire immediately behind cable seal ( Figure 44).

figure.caption: Cut Wire Immediately Behind Cable Seal

step1.para: Slip new cable seal onto wire in direction shown. Strip .22 in. ± 0.02 in. (5.5 mm ± 0.5 mm) insulation from wire. Position cable seal as shown in Figure 45.

figure.caption: Strip Approximately .22 Inch Insulation From Wire

step1.para: Using standard crimp tool (12085270) or equivalent ( Figure 46), crimp a new terminal onto the wire. The core crimp may be soldered with rosin core solder.
Insulation crimp must grip cable seals as shown in Figure 47.
Insert new terminals into connector until they click ( Figure 48) and lock into place. Be sure to maintain indexing by placing the proper wires into the same cavities as the original connector.
Close and latch secondary lock on connector body, and mate the connector halves ( Figure 49).

svcsubproc.title: Series 56 Connector Terminal Removal
svcsubproc.para: The Series 56 Packard connectors ( Figure 50) provide positive locking of both connectors and terminals. The female terminal has a spring-loaded tang that maintains constant pressure against the male blade to provide positive contact.

On female terminals, insert a fine blade screwdriver ( Figure 51) between the terminal's locking tang. Then pull on the cable to remove the terminal. If wire is disconnected, use needle-nose pliers to pull terminal from the connector.

figure.caption: Insert Screwdriver Between Terminal's Locking Tang

svcsubproc.para: On many terminals ( Figure 52), insert a fine blade between the locking tang and the insulator to compress the tang. Then pull on the cable to remove the terminal. If wire is disconnected, use needle-nose pliers to pull terminal from the connector.

figure.caption: Insert Blade Between Locking Tang and Insulator

svcsubproc.title: Series 56 Connector Terminal/Wire Assembly
svcsubproc.para: For the following procedure to install terminals on the wire, refer to Figure 53and Figure 54.

step1.para: Strip approximately 1/4 inch (6.3 mm) of insulation from the end of the wire.
Insert the wire into the box (on female terminal) or blade (on male terminal), and core base of the terminal.
Using Packard crimping tool (12085270) or equivalent, crimp the core wings so that the wire core is visible, extending slightly past the core wings.
Crimp the insulation wings so that the wings cover the insulation of wire. No core should be visible under the insulation wings.

On female terminals, make certain that the box rails are straight, that box and core base are straight, and that the tang protrudes to lock the terminal in place when installed in the insulator connector.

svcsubproc.title: Series 56 Connector Terminal Installation
svcsubproc.para: Both female and male terminals are installed into the connector body by pushing the terminal/wire assembly into the back of the connector. The locking tang will lock the terminal into place when the terminal has been fully inserted. On male terminals, make certain that the tang is not bent inward. If it is bent, use a fine-blade screwdriver to push the tang out into its proper position. Tug on the wire to make certain that the terminal is seated and locked into place.

svcsubproc.title: Micro-Pack Connector Terminal Removal
svcsubproc.para: To remove terminals from the Micro-Pack connector, refer to the following procedure. The terminals are inserted and removed from the back of the connector. Terminals are installed on the wires in the same manner described above.

step1.para: Remove the loose-piece comb lock. Do not use terminal removal tool for this step; damage to the tool may result.
Grasp the lead and push the terminal forward to the most forward position ( Figure 55).

figure.caption: Push Terminal Forward to Most Forward Position

step1.para: Locate the terminal lock tang in the connector cavity, then insert the Terminal Removal Tool straight into the front of the connector cavity as shown in Figure 56. Do not angle or rock the tool because it could damage the connector wall.

figure.caption: Insert Tool Straight into Front of Connector Cavity

step1.para: While holding the tool securely in place, gently pull on the cable to remove terminal. Never use force to remove the tool.
Visually inspect the terminal and connector for damage, and replace if necessary ( Figure 57). Replace the terminal if the radius of tang is flattened or terminal is otherwise damaged.

figure.caption: Inspect Terminal and Connector For Damage

svcsubproc.para: After repair is complete, insert Comb/Terminal Position Assurances, or lock secondary lock after repair is made. Do not re-use a damaged comb ( Figure 57).

svcsubproc.title: Metri-Pack Terminal Removal (Pull-To-Seat) - Installing Terminals
svcsubproc.para: Connectors discussed here use Weather Pack Seals inserted into the shell of the connector instead of being installed on each wire. To remove terminals from the Metri- Pack connector, refer to the following procedure.
Terminals are installed on the wires after wire has been pushed through the connector. Do not strip the wire until it has been pushed through to avoid fraying the wire strands.

step1.para: From the back side of the connector, insert the wire (unstripped) through the seal and correct cavity of the connector, so that it protrudes from the mating end of the connector.
Strip insulation to leave 0.2 inch (5 mm) of bare wire end (do not cut wire strands).

Use 12085271 (or other appropriate crimper) to crimp terminal to wire. Inspect terminal for correct installation. Be sure there are no cut strands. Pull test to 10 - 15 lbs. to be sure the terminal is on securely.
To install, pull gently back into the connector until it locks into place.

svcsubproc.title: Metri-Pack Terminal Removal (Pull-To-Seat) - Removing Terminals From Connector

step1.para: If applicable, remove Comb/Terminal Position Assurance (TPA) using appropriate tool. Do not use the terminal removal tool for this step as damage will result.
Choose the correct size pick to use by the size of the entry canal.
Using the pick, locate terminal lock tang in the connector.
Insert pick straight into entry canal at front of connector ( Figure 58).

figure.caption: Insert Pick Straight into Entry Canal

step1.para: Depress lock tang to unseat terminal. Never use force to pull terminal out of connector.
Gently push on cable to remove terminal through the front of the connector.
Inspect the terminal and wire for damage and replace if necessary. If applicable, insert Comb/Terminal Position Assurance (TPA) after repair has been made.

svcsubproc.title: Additional Connectors
svcsubproc.para: Several different types of electrical connectors are used on International vehicles. Refer to Figure 59, Figure 60and Figure 61for additional connector illustrations.

calloutgroup.callout1: F. PACK CON I AND II (FEMALE)
G. PACK CON (FEMALE) HEAVY DUTY/III SERIES
